Twenty-one municipalities, including the cities of Vilnius, Kaunas and Klaipeda, have been previously red-zoned and quarantined.   – Facemasks are mandatory in all public places.  – One-metre space must be observed in inter-city public transport.  – Groups of more than five people are not allowed, except members of the same household.  – Two-metre distances must be maintained between groups in events and public places.  – Public-sector institutions are switching fully or partially to remote work.  – Retail businesses must manage client flows, ensuring a space of at least 10 square metres per customer.  – Hospital visits are suspended, except in cases where patients are terminally ill, under 14 years old, or women in maternity wards.  – Religious communities are advised to suspend services or avoid crowding.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104191028/https://www.lrt.lt/en/news-in-english/19/1267705/lithuania-adds-13-municipalities-to-coronavirus-red-zone
No change in previous policy

In view of the epidemiological assessments of the growing risks of spread of the COVID-19 virus, a national state of emergency will be declared in Latvia, to be in effect between 9 November and 6 December.    All in-person public events (such as theatre and music performances) are cancelled and banned. No more than 10 people, and members of no more than two households may participate in private meetings. No more than 50 people may participate in public gatherings, rallies and political demonstrations. Members of more than two households may attend to a funeral, up to a total of 10 people (not including the individuals conducting the funerary proceedings).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113081120/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/state-emergency-be-declared-latvia-9-november
No change to previous policy (running until 6th December by latest legislation).

After returning from foreign countries with a high incidence of Covid-19, observing a 10-day self-isolation is mandatory. When arriving in Latvia by passenger carrier transport, a form must be completed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113091405/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/careful-travel/persons-who-wish-arrive-latvia

No change to previous entry:    "Currently, the actions that people are required to take after returning from abroad depend on the morbidity rates in the country where they have been: if in the last 14 days one has been in an EU, EEA, or a separate country with a 14-day cumulative number of Covid-19 cases that exceeds 50 people per 100,000 inhabitants (see list here) or if one has spent time in a third country, one must observe self-isolation. If one is returning to Latvia from the EU, EEA, or a separate country where the above-mentioned indicator does not exceed 50 people, one is not required to observe self-isolation. However, if one transits through any “unsafe countries” on the route back from a “safe” country, then self-isolation must be observed; in order to avoid the need to observe self-isolation, one must choose a safer return route"    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113091405/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/careful-travel/persons-who-wish-arrive-latvia  https://web.archive.org/save/https://covid19.gov.lv/index.php/en/support-society/careful-travel/after-arrival-latvia

Given the awareness of the effect that the state-of-emergency measures can have on the economy and the general public, a support mechanism is being developed to support employers, employees and those parts of the public most likely to be affected by the measures introduced to limit the spread of the virus.    Measures will be implemented on November 12th.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113081120/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/state-emergency-be-declared-latvia-9-november

While Covid-19 restrictions continue, the government has decided on support measures to companies suffering from Covid-19. The government has approved the following support measures:    "Self-employed persons who apply the general tax payment regime, persons who receive royalties, who have not registered as performers of economic activities, and sole proprietorships whose economic activity has been suspended as a result of the restrictions, or whose income from economic activity has decreased by at least 20% in comparison to this year’s August, September and October, will be eligible for support in the amount of 75% of the average income from economic activity or royalties during Q3 this year; but not exceeding EUR 1,000."    "Self-employed persons who pay the micro-enterprise tax will be eligible for 50% of monthly average income for Q3 this year. Payers of patent payments will be eligible for support of EUR 330."    "Employees working at companies affected by Covid-19 will be eligible for idle-time payment. This support will be at least EUR 330, but not more than EUR 1,000 a month. In addition to idle-time payment, the employee can receive an extra EUR 50 for each dependent child under 24."    "The regulations state that support as compensation for idle time will be paid to the employee at the amount of 70% of the reported monthly average gross salary from 1 August to 30 October this year or of the reported monthly average gross salary for those months after 1 August when the employee actually worked. An employee of a micro-enterprise taxpayer will be eligible for idle-time payment of 50% of the monthly average gross salary at the micro-enterprise for Q3 2020."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201118091001/https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=293a20d7-ee9e-4c68-8962-4dca8247c181

No change to previous measures. Broad economic relief and support available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113092303/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/economics/entrepreneurs/support-entrepreneurs

No change to previous entry    How can COVID-19 be analyzed?  From October 26, there is a new testing procedure. If Covid-19 is suspected, you should first contact your doctor. If the healthcare professional, after hearing the patient about their symptoms, decides that a test is needed, an e-mail will be issued. Then, when the person calls 8303, he or she will be queued for the test as soon as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026224302/https://covid19.gov.lv/biezak-uzdotie-jautajumi

Face masks must be worn:    On public transport;  In taxis by passengers and by the driver, if a special barrier, such as a separating wall, is not installed;  At bus stations, railway stations, ports, and airports;  In a shop, pharmacy, post office, gas station, and other indoor points of sale;  In markets and outdoor street shopping venues;  In a museum, library, exhibition hall, and in other cultural venues;  In churches;  In any other public place;  Providing and receiving services;  In medical institutions;  In the common areas of educational institutions (both children aged 13 and over and teachers).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113094112/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions-and-answers

Face masks must be worn:    "On public transport;  In taxis by passengers and by the driver, if a special barrier, such as a separating wall, is not installed;  At bus stations, railway stations, ports, and airports;  In a shop, pharmacy, post office, gas station, and other indoor points of sale;  In markets and outdoor street shopping venues;  In a museum, library, exhibition hall, and in other cultural venues;  In churches;  In any other public place;  Providing and receiving services;  In medical institutions;  In the common areas of educational institutions (both children aged 13 and over and teachers)."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113094112/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions-and-answers    - A homemade mask should be made of at least three layers of suitable material (cotton, nylon, etc.) and have ties to secure it behind the ears or behind the head  - Wearing a face mask is not obligatory for children under 13 years of age or for people who have difficulty wearing a mask, for example, due to functional disorders  - Wearing a face mask is obligatory from the age of 13 outside the classroom at an educational establishment    https://web.archive.org/web/20201118093618/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled to establish emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova on the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021:  Ban the activity of night clubs (disco clubs, karaoke, disco pubs), starting from 28 November. At the same time, as of 30 November, the restaurants, pubs and coffee houses will be able to work till 22:00. The public nourishment units will be banned from working in the time interval 22:00-7:00.    The organization and holding of scientific conferences, sports competitions, Olympiads with the physical presence of people will be prohibited. Also, the presence of audience in theatres, movie theatres, concert halls and community centres will not be allowed.    At the same time, the public and private institutions will establish a special regime of work, with only the strictly necessary staff attracted to the working place, in order to ensure the enterprises’ functionality. The distance work will have to be organized for the personnel, whose activity does not need the compulsory presence at the working place.        https://web.archive.org/web/20201205215306/https://gov.md/en/content/national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-declares-state-emergency-public-health-all   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205214717/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

A comprehensive fiscal package has been adopted as per two 2020 State Budget Amendments, following several targeted fiscal measures to support businesses and vulnerable households, such as expanding unemployment benefits and strengthening existing targeted social assistance, tax relief for sectors affected by state-imposed restrictions, delaying tax payment deadlines to mid-2020, suspending tax audits and other controls, and increasing state budget allocations to the budget emergency and health funds and to a mortgage guarantee program.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201125052550/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No change in policy.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201205211537/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled to establish emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova on the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021:  Face-masks are mandatory in all public spaces, including outdoors.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201205215306/https://gov.md/en/content/national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-declares-state-emergency-public-health-all   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205214717/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

From 10 PM on 4th Nov,  Groups  - Indoors and outdoors: max. 2 people or 1 household    Education  - In secondary and higher education face masks must be worn outside lessons    Venues normally open to the public  - Closure of museums, cinemas, theatres, zoos, swimming pools, libraries, sex establishments, amusement parks and other venues.    Food and drink / events  - Restaurants, bars and cafés remain closed.  - Takeaway restaurants can stay open. No alcohol may be sold or delivered after 20.00.  - Events are banned. Exceptions include funerals and demonstrations.    At Home  - Stay at home as much as possible.  - No more than 2 visitors per day (excluding children under 13).  - Follow the rules for selfquarantine and isolation.    Shops  - Shops close no later than 20.00. Except supermarkets, general markets and other stores that sell groceries.  - Ban on alcohol after 20.00. This applies to sales, deliveries and drinking alcohol in public spaces.    Transport  - Within the Netherlands: essential travel only.  - Do not travel abroad or book trips abroad. Travelling within the Kingdom is allowed.  - Wear a face mask on public transport.    Sport:   - no more than 2 people. Stay 1.5 metres apart. This does not apply to children under 18 and elite athletes  - No matches or competitions. With the exception of elite athletes.  - No spectators.  - Sports canteens, showers and changing rooms remain closed.  - No group lessons.     Link - http://web.archive.org/web/20201107144025/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/binaries/rijksoverheid/documenten/publicaties/2020/11/03/coronavirus-factsheet-tijdelijke-verzwaring-van-de-gedeeltelijke-lockdown-vertalingen/201103_Maatr_3Nov_EN_02.pdf    Budget - http://web.archive.org/web/20201109113559/https://www.rijksfinancien.nl/overheidsfinancien-coronatijd/noodmaatregelen/uitgavenmaatregelen/noodmaatregelen-coronacrisis

"Primary and secondary schools remain open. Students in secondary and higher education institutions must wear a face mask when not in class.  Children must stay home if they have symptoms or if someone in their household is waiting for a COVID-19 test result or if someone tests positive for COVID-19.  Colleges and universities should host virtual orientation sessions."  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://nl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-3/

"A maximum of 3 guests are permitted in private residences in both indoor and outdoor areas per day. This is in addition to the members of the household.  Guests should also be asked whether they have any symptoms and if they do, should not be received. "Is public transportation operating? YES   Non-surgical face masks are mandatory on public transport including trains, trams, buses, taxis, and passenger vans. "While it is strongly advised not to travel to the Netherlands (except if it's strictly necessary), the borders remain open to certain countries, specifically those in EU and those from "Australia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Uruguay, and China (once China starts readmitting European travellers)." "If you do travel to the Netherlands, you are strongly advised to self-quarantine for 10 days." Further, there are exemptions to the entry ban, including those with economic interests, elite athletes and support staff, cultural and creative sectors, professional journalists, and researchers.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130222612/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/travel-and-holidays/visiting-the-netherlands  https://web.archive.org/web/20201123225841/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/travel-and-holidays/visiting-the-netherlands-exemptions-to-the-entry-ban

From 10 PM on 4th Nov,  Groups  - Indoors and outdoors: max. 2 people or 1 household    Education  - In secondary and higher education face masks must be worn outside lessons    Venues normally open to the public  - Closure of museums, cinemas, theatres, zoos, swimming pools, libraries, sex establishments, amusement parks and other venues.    Food and drink / events  - Restaurants, bars and cafés remain closed.  - Takeaway restaurants can stay open. No alcohol may be sold or delivered after 20.00.  - Events are banned. Exceptions include funerals and demonstrations.    At Home  - Stay at home as much as possible.  - No more than 2 visitors per day (excluding children under 13).  - Follow the rules for selfquarantine and isolation.    Shops  - Shops close no later than 20.00. Except supermarkets, general markets and other stores that sell groceries.  - Ban on alcohol after 20.00. This applies to sales, deliveries and drinking alcohol in public spaces.    Transport  - Within the Netherlands: essential travel only.  - Do not travel abroad or book trips abroad. Travelling within the Kingdom is allowed.  - Wear a face mask on public transport.    Sport:   - no more than 2 people. Stay 1.5 metres apart. This does not apply to children under 18 and elite athletes  - No matches or competitions. With the exception of elite athletes.  - No spectators.  - Sports canteens, showers and changing rooms remain closed.  - No group lessons.     Link - http://web.archive.org/web/20201107144025/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/binaries/rijksoverheid/documenten/publicaties/2020/11/03/coronavirus-factsheet-tijdelijke-verzwaring-van-de-gedeeltelijke-lockdown-vertalingen/201103_Maatr_3Nov_EN_02.pdf    Budget - http://web.archive.org/web/20201109113559/https://www.rijksfinancien.nl/overheidsfinancien-coronatijd/noodmaatregelen/uitgavenmaatregelen/noodmaatregelen-coronacrisis

"If you test positive for coronavirus, the municipal health service (GGD) will carry out contact tracing." The Norwegian Institute of Public Health (NIPH/FHI) recommends that anyone who suspects they might be infected by the coronavirus is given the opportunity to be tested. Those that should get tested are:    Anyone showing symptoms of COVID-19, including anyone experiencing a sudden onset of symptoms of a respiratory tract infection.  Anyone who is a close contact to someone with confirmed COVID-19*.  Anyone arriving in Norway after having visited a red contry/area during the preceding 10-day period.  Anyone who suspects they might be infected by the coronavirus.  Other persons as assessed by a doctor.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113155943/https://www.helsenorge.no/en/coronavirus/testing-symptoms-and-close-contacts/

If your test result comes back positive, you will be contacted by the local municipality and placed in isolation. The municipality will initiate contact tracing, and you will be asked to provide information on your close contacts during the preceding 48-hours period. The municipality will get in touch with your close contacts to inform them of their quarantine duty.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113155943/https://www.helsenorge.no/en/coronavirus/testing-symptoms-and-close-contacts/

Pupils:  grades IV-VIII of primary schools,  all grades of post-primary schools,  students of continuing education institutions,  vocational training centers  they learn remotely.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104172405/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

Students of all grades of primary schools, all grades of post-primary schools, students of continuing education institutions and vocational training centers, learn remotely.  The kindergartens function without any changes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109091112/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

Currently, the activities of swimming pools, aquaparks, gyms, clubs and fitness centers are suspended, except for those which:   operate in entities that perform medical activities intended for patients,  are intended for people practicing sports as part of sports competition, sports activities or sports events,  are intended for students and pupils - as part of classes at the university or school.    Night clubs closed.   Cultural events - incl. theater performances, screenings in the cinema or classes in a community center, may be held with the participation of 25% of the audience, with every fourth seat available in the audience, alternating rows.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104172405/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

Activities of cultural institutions, including theaters, cinemas, museums, art galleries, community centers, is suspended. Important! Libraries are also suspended.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201109091112/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

Shopping centres were allowed to reopen on November 28 but restaurants, fitness clubs, cinemas and theatres have to remain closed at least until December 27.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201128124300/https://www.themayor.eu/en/poland-presents-100-day-battle-plan-for-fight-against-covid-19
Forbidden to organise weddings, communions, and other celebrations or parties.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104172405/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

A maximum of 5 people. Participants are required to cover their nose and mouth and keep 1.5 m away from other people. Moreover, the distance between assemblies must not be less than 100 m.    It is forbidden to organize meetings and events of any kind - with the exception of events and meetings organized at home in which up to 20 people participate.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104172405/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia
A limited number of people can travel by public transport.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104172405/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

Senior, stay home! We call for limiting the movement of seniors - especially people over 70 years of age.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201104172405/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

After the approval of the Health Delegate, Dr. Manuel Galego, all establishments in the Borba School Group, as well as in the schools in the municipality of Vila Viçosa, will reopen and resume their face-to face activities on 6th of November ( Friday), according to the rules of the DGS, fulfilling the schedule of each class."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201201205821/https://odigital.pt/covid-19-escolas-do-concelho-de-borba-reabrem-na-sexta-feira/

The Regional Government of the Azores announced that the 18 schools, both private and public, in the island of São Miguel where cases of COVID-19 were detected will be closed from November 16 until December 1.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201201210723if_/https://www.noticiasaominuto.com/pais/1627066/secretaria-atualiza-para-18-as-escolas-que-vao-fechar-nos-acores

Previous coding should be changed to 3T since all schools were closed in the islands.    In the Azores, schools have been closed for almost two weeks because of the pandemic and parents of students without access to any social support.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201205220605/https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/seguranca-social/detalhe/nos-acores-ha-escolas-fechadas-e-pais-sem-apoio-ha-varios-dias-psd-pede-audicao-urgente-a-ministra

Schools, kindergartens, kindergartens and ATLs will close in the next two Mondays (30/11 and 7/12)    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201205214334/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2020-11-24-Escolas-fechadas-nas-pontes-de-feriados.-Pais-ainda-nao-sabem-se-vao-ter-apoio-do-Estado  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205203200/https://pt.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The previous coding should be changed to 3T since all schools were closed.    Azores reopen 15 schools and keep seven closed.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201205220521/https://observador.pt/2020/12/03/covid-19-acores-reabrem-15-escolas-e-mantem-sete-encerradas/

"Lisbon, Nov. 9, 2020 (Lusa) Portugal on Monday entered a state of emergency to last until 23 November as part of the effort to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, with the imposition among other measures of an overnight curfew in 121 municipalities deemed to be most at risk in terms of new infections. The curfew, under which residents must on weekdays be off the streets from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. and on the next two weekends from 1 p.m. to 5 a.m., is in force in municipalities that together have 70% of Portugal's population, including all those in the Lisbon and Porto Metropolitan Areas."  "Special measures were adopted in 114 municipalities considered to be at high risk, until 23 November, increasing to 191 municipalities 0 a.m. on 16 November: (...) - Closing of shops until 10 p.m.; - Restaurants with groups limited to 6 people and running until 10.30 p.m.; - Restaurant establishments exclusive to home delivery services may close until 1 a.m.  (...) Bars and Nightclubs: They remain closed and may operate only as cafes or pastries and are subject to the rules specified for these establishments."  Note: These measures are only in place in mainland Portugal hence the T flag.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123150158/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/node/421175%C2%A0 https://archive.vn/PI5M8

"Portugal on Monday entered a state of emergency to last until 23 November as part of the effort to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, with the imposition among other measures of an overnight curfew in 121 municipalities deemed to be most at risk in terms of new infections.    The curfew, under which residents must on weekdays be off the streets from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. and on the next two weekends from 1 p.m. to 5 a.m., is in force in municipalities that together have 70% of Portugal's population, including all those in the Lisbon and Porto Metropolitan Areas."    During the weekends only some essential services are allowed to remain open after 1pm, including (but not limited to) pharmacies, restaurants (only takeaway), clinics and grocery stores.    Note: These measures are in place only in some municipalities in mainland Portugal hence the T flag.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123165935/https://www.lusa.pt/article/x_xHGVJAjhAWMF_8vRQGPTMSZM5iuSI1/portugal-country-starts-15-day-state-of-emergency-curfew-in-high-risk-areas  http://web.archive.org/web/20201123171334/https://expresso.pt/politica/2020-11-13-Saiba-quais-sao-os-estabelecimentos-que-podem-estar-abertos-este-fim-de-semana-depois-das-13h

The curfew, under which residents must on weekdays be off the streets from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. and on the next two weekends from 1 p.m. to 5 a.m., is in force in municipalities that together have 70% of Portugal's population, including all those in the Lisbon and Porto Metropolitan Areas."    During the weekends only some essential services are allowed to remain open after 1pm, including (but not limited to) pharmacies, restaurants (only takeaway), clinics and grocery stores.    Note: These measures are in place only in some municipalities in mainland Portugal hence the T flag. "Lisbon, Nov. 9, 2020 (Lusa) Portugal on Monday entered a state of emergency to last until 23 November as part of the effort to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, with the imposition among other measures of an overnight curfew in 121 municipalities deemed to be most at risk in terms of new infections. The curfew, under which residents must on weekdays be off the streets from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. and on the next two weekends from 1 p.m. to 5 a.m., is in force in municipalities that together have 70% of Portugal's population, including all those in the Lisbon and Porto Metropolitan Areas."  "Special measures were adopted in 114 municipalities considered to be at high risk, until 23 November, increasing to 191 municipalities 0 a.m. on 16 November: (...) - Closing of shops until 10 p.m.; - Restaurants with groups limited to 6 people and running until 10.30 p.m.; - Restaurant establishments exclusive to home delivery services may close until 1 a.m.  (...) Bars and Nightclubs: They remain closed and may operate only as cafes or pastries and are subject to the rules specified for these establishments."  Note: These measures are only in place in mainland Portugal hence the T flag.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123150158/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/node/421175%C2%A0 https://archive.vn/PI5M8

Subject to the restrictions in your municipality and the rules on social distancing, hand hygiene and the use of face coverings, most shops and services, restaurants, cultural venues and sports facilities are open. Opening and closing times may vary between municipalities.    As required by the State of Emergency, shops closed at 1 pm in the counties where there is a greater risk of transmission of the new coronavirus. There are already 127 municipalities in this situation.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201205224640/https://www.rtp.pt/noticias/pais/comercio-encerrado-a-tarde-em-127-municipios_v1279061    Teleworking is mandatory in all high, very high and extreme risk counties, whenever the functions in question permit and the worker has conditions to perform them, without the need for a written agreement between employer and worker.  Who does the telework obligation apply to?  - Companies that work in the municipalities mentioned above; and  - To workers, regardless of employment, who reside or work in any of the municipalities mentioned above.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201205224830/https://covid19estamoson.gov.pt/regimes-de-teletrabalho/

"Portugal on Monday entered a state of emergency to last until 23 November as part of the effort to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, with the imposition among other measures of an overnight curfew in 121 municipalities deemed to be most at risk in terms of new infections.  The curfew, under which residents must on weekdays be off the streets from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. and on the next two weekends from 1 p.m. to 5 a.m., is in force in municipalities that together have 70% of Portugal's population, including all those in the Lisbon and Porto Metropolitan Areas.  The measure, which was approved by the cabinet at an extraordinary meeting on Saturday evening, foresees exceptions such as journeys to work or to return home, emergency situations, a daily walk in the vicinity of home, or taking a pet for a walk.  (...) A number of measures had already been approved by the government last week, including limiting groups in restaurants to six people, unless they belong to the same household."  Note: These measures are in place only in some municipalities in mainland Portugal hence the T flag.  Source: https://archive.vn/PI5M8

"Taking into consideration the epidemiological situation in Portugal, the Government decided to renew the state of calamity throughout the national territory until 11:59 pm on 15 November 2020 and to extend to other municipalities the special measures that had been established for the municipalities of Felgueiras, Lousada and Paços de Ferreira, introducing some additional changes.  Thus, for the municipalities covered by the new measures, the Council of Ministers determined: - The duty to remain at home, and citizens should refrain from circulating in public spaces and roads, as well as in spaces and private roads equivalent to public roads (exceptions previously announced) to which are added: trips for activities carried out in day centers, to visit the elderly, to go to stations and post offices, bank agencies and agencies insurance brokers or insurance companies and the travel required to leave mainland Portugal (...)"  (...) These exceptional measures will be imposed from November 4th and will apply to a total of 121 municipalities"  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123155630/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/comunicacao/noticia?i=novas-medidas-para-combater-a-pandemia

-All counties:  Prohibition of movement between municipalities in the following periods:  Between 11 pm on 27 November and 5 am on 2 December;  Between 11 pm on December 4 and 5 am on December 9;  -High-risk counties (> 240 cases):  Prohibition of circulation on public roads between 11 pm and 5 am;  Closing of commercial establishments at 10 pm;  Closure of restaurants and cultural facilities at 10:30 pm.  -Very high and extremely high risk counties (> 480 cases):  Prohibition of circulation on public roads between 11 pm and 5 am on weekdays;  Prohibition of circulation on public roads and closure of commercial establishments between 1 pm and 5 am on the following days:  Saturdays, Sundays and holidays (from December 1 and December 8):  Holiday Eve (November 30 and December 7): closure of commercial establishments from 3 pm.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201205223531/https://roma.embaixadaportugal.mne.gov.pt/pt/a-embaixada/noticias/renovacao-do-estado-de-emergencia-em-portugal  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205223554/https://jornaleconomico.sapo.pt/noticias/estado-de-emergencia-estas-sao-as-restricoes-que-vao-vigorar-ate-8-de-dezembro-668015

The 2021 state budget adopted on November 26 foresees further support to the national health system, employment and incomes of households and firms. Key measures include:   (i) income support measures, such as temporary reduction of PIT withholdings (0.1 percent of GDP);   (ii) expanded subsidy for employment and resumption of activity (0.5 percent of GDP) and extended support for workers' lost income and coverage for those without access to unemployment protection (0.2 percent of GDP);   (iii) staff reinforcement in the civil service, particularly in health and education (0.1 percent of GDP) and an extraordinary risk subsidy in the amount of 20 percent of base salary for health professionals at the forefront of the response to COVID-19; and   (iv) VAT tax rebate to stimulate consumption in the catering sectors, accommodation and culture by returning the VAT paid on consumption in these sectors (0.1 percent GDP).

The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities. Also, the Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance).  Link: https://archive.fo/cUlEp, https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf and https://archive.fo/1JWbz

With a few exceptions, Georgia remains closed to foreign travelers. The entry ban for foreign citizens applies to air, land, and sea borders, including foreign citizens who are legal residents of Georgia, or have been living and working in Georgia, or own property or business.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201106191444/https://ge.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-on-georgia/ and https://archive.fo/kYCaw

On 26th of October, The National Committee for Emergency Situations published Decision no.50 regarding the approval of the list of countries/areas of epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on persons arriving in Romania from them. Also, there are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions).    Link: https://archive.fo/QHwSB and  https://archive.fo/9KkOQ

On 20th of November, The National Committee for Emergency Situations published Decision no.55 regarding the approval of the list of countries/areas of epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on persons arriving in Romania from them. Also, there are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions).    Link: https://archive.fo/9KkOQ and https://archive.fo/lIjB1

The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers.  According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://archive.fo/hVM21

Multiple documents were published to prevent spread of Coronavirus through “stopcov.ge”, the official Georgian government’s website: “Recommendations on Personal Hygiene”, “Simple recommendations to protect yourself from COVID-19”, “Rules for Self-Isolation” and “Special Guidance for Risk Groups”.   Links: https://archive.fo/Lq3cv  and https://archive.fo/wip/WpeX6

Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”. On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases. Also, “Datelazi.ro” (Updated data) project was released pro-bon by Code for Romania in partnership with the Government of Romania through the Authority for the Digitalization of Romania, containing data and information provided by the Government of Romania.   Links: https://archive.fo/cUlEp, https://archive.fo/klswT , https://archive.fo/Vi0vG and https://archive.fo/X428Q

The Fourth Revision of Report of the National Center for Disease Control and Public Health published the details of testing policy.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/Sm4IX and https://archive.fo/wip/WGczm

According to the Ministry of Health, the units that are accredited by the Ministry of Health to perform the diagnosis by RT-PCR have the obligation to provide priority diagnosis for patients in health facilities, suspects in epidemiological investigations, and people at risk, according to the methodology of the National Institute of Public Health – National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases.   Link: https://archive.fo/6K5UM

The Fourth Revision of Report of the National Center for Disease Control and Public Health published the details of contract tracing.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/Sm4IX and https://archive.fo/wip/WGczm

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr

Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr

Face masks must be worn in all enclosed public spaces, including taxis and public transportation. Violators of face musk rules are subject to a 20 GEL (about 6 USD) fine. There are some exceptions for children under 6, people with disabilities, or who have health problems that prevent them from wearing a face covering.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201106191444/https://ge.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-on-georgia/

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces, regardless the value of the cumulative incidence rate of cases in the last 14 days (as it previously of this decision was). These restrictions are imposed from November 13, 2020 and will be in effect for two months - until January 15, 2021.  1. Students of city universities and colleges move to a remote form of education. The Government of Moscow recommends that the founders of federal and private universities and colleges make similar decisions.  Transport cards of students transferred to distance learning will be temporarily blocked.  2. Schoolchildren and students who have been transferred to a remote form of study are advised to observe the home regime and to minimize travel around the city.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122202923/https://www.sobyanin.ru/koronavirus-resheniya-10-11-2020

For example,  in Moscow, schools have transitioned to online learning for higher grades. All universities and colleges in Moscow also now must conduct classes through distance learning. See https://web.archive.org/web/20201130221914/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in policy. The eastern Siberian republic of Buryatia became the first Russian region to impose a second coronavirus lockdown. From November 16 to November 30, 2020, restaurants, cafes, canteens, buffets, bars, eateries and other catering facilities have been suspended, except for takeaway services without citizens visiting the premises of such enterprises, as well as delivering orders. Cinemas, beauty salons, baths and saunas are also closed for two weeks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201122203043/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2020/11/22/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-nov-22-a69117  https://web.archive.org/web/20201122211741/https://egov-buryatia.ru/press_center/news/detail.php?ID=79386

Testing in widely available in Russia, both through government healthcare providers and private clinics. Testing is free at government healthcare providers for those suspected of having coronavirus.  In Moscow, residents of Russia who have mandatory medical insurance may schedule a free test at any time at one of 207 government healthcare providers in Moscow that provide testing.  Private clinics also provide COVID testing on a fee-basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122205355/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A small change to the previous policy, whereby secondary schools and grades 5-9 of primary schools were closed while kindergartens and primary grades 1-4 were allowed to remained open. Starting on 16 Nov 2020, "pupils from a disadvantaged environment who do not have suitable conditions for remote learning are allowed to return to school and attend classes in small numbers, with no more than five pupils in the group, plus one teacher."    Source: The Slovak Spectator    http://web.archive.org/web/20201130220822/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22536069/coronavirus-in-slovakia-measures-in-place-after-november-16.html

No changes in school policy until 07 December, when primary and secondary schools will be able to re-open if they can implement rapid testing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201205231538/https://www.uvzsr.sk/docs/info/ut/ciastka_20_2020.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205232259/https://korona.gov.sk/

As a result, cinemas, theatres and churches were open on November 16, while some sports competitions were given a green light, although without spectators. Greater restrictions at the border as Slovakia adopts the European (ECDC) methodology to deem countries risky or less risky. All EU borders are now considered red. Those arriving from red zones are required to present a negative PCR test no older than 72 hours, register with the government website and self-isolate. Exemptions are in place for cross-border workers.     Source: The Slovak Spectator     http://web.archive.org/web/20201130220822/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22536069/coronavirus-in-slovakia-measures-in-place-after-november-16.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20201128021316/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22504724/coronavirus-in-slovakia-return-from-red-countries.html

The government of Slovenia maintains a color-coded system of entry / quarantine restrictions:  A very small number of countries are designated “green” (epidemiologically safe).  A much larger list of countries, including the United States, are designated as “red” (poor epidemiological conditions).  In some cases, regions of countries are listed as “red.”  All non-listed countries/regions of countries  are designated “orange” (aggravated epidemiological situation).   Travelers who have spent 14 days in either a “green” country or an “orange” EU country/region can enter Slovenia without quarantine.  All others must quarantine 10 days or have a negative result from a Covid test taken in the EU within the prior 48 hours.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201121172736/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Employers are recommended to tell employees to work from home if they can. Restaurants and bars are open with social distancing rules in place. The ban on public gatherings and public events with more than 50 people does not apply to workplaces.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201121190718/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/employees-employers-and-businesses

On 24 Nov, a new ban on public gatherings of over 8 people came into effect. This does not apply to most workplaces, but does affect some sectors to the point where they are required to close, such as amusement parks, markets and fairs. For theaters and cinemas, the official rule is that seated audiences of up to 300 are allowed as long as social distancing measures are adhered to, although the reality on the ground is much stricter as the regions have issued non-binding recommendations which extend the 8-people limit to seated audiences.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130190632/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130190831/https://www.thelocal.se/20201123/no-public-events-for-more-than-8-people-in-sweden-including-seated-events

"Starting from November 1st, seated audiences of up to 300 people will be permitted at cultural and sports events, if a one-metre distance can be kept between groups. Groups of two attending together will be allowed to sit next to each other without a one-metre distance.  Currently, there is a limit of 50 people for public events, which has been in place since late March. This has applied to all public events, including concerts, theatre performances, sports matches, lectures and demonstrations, and the 50-person limit will remain in place for events which can't ensure designated seating and distancing.  These limits are not recommendations or guidelines, but are legal bans imposed by the government under Sweden's Public Order Act."  Note: Since the 50 person limit still applies in some cases the code has not been updated.  Source: https://archive.vn/fPl12

The prohibition of public gatherings of more than 50 people applies to public events that are covered by the Public Order Act. However, there are several exceptions to this rule. The limit is 300 participants for events where the members of the audience are seated and have at least one meter distance to other persons. Two people from the same group may be seated closer together. Local and regional differences exist. Several regions that have introduced stricter general guidelines have chosen to maintain the previous limit of a maximum of 50 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122092744/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    Note: in line with previous coding, code has not changed because 300-people rule does not apply to all public events and those events that cannot realize the social distancing measures in the audience are still required to be cancelled.

On 24 Nov, a new ban on public gatherings of over 8 people came into effect. The exception for seated audiences of up to 300 (as long as social distancing measures are adhered to) remains in place, although the reality on the ground is much stricter as the regions have issued non-binding recommendations which extend the 8-people limit to seated audiences.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130190632/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130190831/https://www.thelocal.se/20201123/no-public-events-for-more-than-8-people-in-sweden-including-seated-events

The restrictions for gatherings are part of the Public Order Act and explicitly only for public gatherings (as cited in the C3 notes), not *private* gatherings under the definition of C4. There is no policy for private gatherings for 2 reasons. First, the rationale of the Swedish government is that it is better to issue recommendations and call on people to follow these and be responsible voluntarily, rather than impose them through legislation. With respect to gatherings, most Swedish regions have recommendations in place which ask everyone to refrain from close contact with people they don't live with and non-essential visits to indoor environments like shops, gyms, and museums, all of which are not covered under the Public Order Act. Prime Minister Stefan Löfven has said that "it's not possible to legislate common sense" but has also made clear that the rules for gathering under the Public Order Act should also set a "norm" for private gatherings, urging people to cancel dinners, parties and trips to gyms or libraries, but these kinds of gatherings are not covered by legislation. A second reason is that the Swedish constitution in its current form does not allow for limits on the number of people who meet privately. See eg: https://web.archive.org/web/20201130183955/https://www.thelocal.se/20201116/breaking-sweden-introduces-limit-of-eight-coronavirus

If possible, travel by other means than public transportation, e.g. by bicycle or walk. If you need to travel by public transport, it is preferable to choose an alternative where it is possible to book a seat in advance, e.g. train.  We advise you to avoid any travel by public transport where you cannot book a seat in advance, e.g. trams, subway and local buses. If this is not possible, ensure physical distance from other people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122094219/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/    Public transportation is operating but services may be limited, both as regards the number of passengers allowed and frequency of departures.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201122095420/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/domestic-travel-and-public-transport

The Public Health Agency has issued regional guidelines for various counties that recommend restricting travel, worded as follows:  Refrain from making unnecessary trips. Travelling can contribute to increasing the spread of infection as you often meet new people. These recommendations do not include travel to work, studies/employment or healthcare appointments that require you to be on site.  This goes for:  Dalarna: 12 Nov-13 Dec  Gävleborg: 16 Nov-13 Dec  Jämtland: 19 Nov-13 Dec  Norrbotten: 10 Nov-13 Dec  Värmland: 12 Nov-13 Dec  Västerbotten: 10 Nov-13 Dec   Västernorrland: 16 Nov-13 Dec  Västmanland: 12 Nov-13 Dec  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130200623/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/regional-guidelines-and-restrictions (click on the names listed above to see the recommendations for that county)

There is a ban on non-essential travel to Sweden, but the ban has numerous exemptions. As of 4 July, the entry ban does not apply to people who:  are an EEA citizen or a citizen of Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, Switzerland or the Vatican City;  have long-term resident status in Sweden or another EU Member State;  have a residence permit in Sweden or another EEA state, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, Switzerland or the Vatican City;  have a national visa for Sweden or a national visa valid longer than three months in another EEA State, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, Switzerland or the Vatican City;  have family ties as specified in Chapter 3a, Section 2, first paragraph, or Chapter 5, Section 3, first paragraph, points 1–4, or Section 3a of the Aliens Act (2005:716) to a person covered by any of points 1–4 or to a Swedish citizen, or  lives in one of the following countries*  Australia  Japan  New Zealand  Rwanda  Singapore  South Korea  Thailand  Uruguay  * This list of countries is continually being revised on an EU-level, and has been changed multiple times.    In addition, the entry ban does not apply to people with an essential need or function in Sweden. For example, this may be the case for:    healthcare workers, researchers in health and medical care and elderly staff;  frontier workers;  seasonal workers in the agricultural, forestry and horticulture sectors;  personnel transporting goods and other staff in the transport sector;  people covered by Chapter 2, Section 10 of the Aliens Act (2005:716);  people who work in international organisations or are invited by such organisations and whose presence is necessary for the organisations’ activities, military personnel, aid workers and civil defence staff;  passengers in transit;  people with imperative family reasons;  seafarers;  people in need of international protection or for other humanitarian reasons;  people who travel for the purpose of studying; and  people travelling for the purpose of performing highly skilled work, if their contribution is necessary from an economic perspective and the work cannot be postponed or performed remotely, including people who will take part in or perform necessary tasks at elite sports competitions.  The above list of people who can be considered to have an essential need or function is for illustration only and there may therefore be other categories of people who may be exempted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122094133/https://www.government.se/articles/2020/04/faqs--entry-to-the-eu-via-sweden-banned/
No change

According to the Public Health Agency, first, the physician or other health care provider determines how a person got infected on the basis of questions about who they have met and where they have been since the first signs of symptoms. Then, household contacts receive rules of conduct (binding under the Swedish Communicable Diseases Act). Third, contact is made with those who may have been exposed to infection. This is done either by the infected person himself, in dialogue with an infection tracker, or by an infection tracker in the respective region.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122193610/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/testning-och-smittsparning/smittsparning/    Note: coded 1 in line with previous coders because the responsibility for contact tracing is largely with the infected individual, not the state.
No change, coded 1 in line with previous coders because the responsibility for contact tracing is largely with the infected individual, not the state.

According to an update of the US Embassy in Turkmenistan on 8 Sep 2020, it seems the Turkmenistan government has imposed measures to restrict large gatherings. But the cap on the number of people is not clear. According to the archived webpage, such measures were not in place on 13 Aug 2020, and then showed up at latest on 8 Sep 2020. Such measures remain in place. All education and training activities for public schools will continue via distance education.   Link: https://archive.fo/uEtHR

Public and private kindergartens can continue education activities in person. All other education and training activities for public schools will continue via distance education.   Link: https://archive.fo/YQtDD and https://archive.fo/uEtHR

Movie theaters, coffee houses, tea gardens, internet/electronic game halls, and billiard halls are suspended. Shopping malls, supermarkets, barbers, and hairdressers will only be open for service during the hours of 10:00-20:00.  Link: https://archive.fo/uEtHR

Movie theaters, coffee houses, tea gardens, internet/electronic game halls, and billiard halls are suspended. Shopping malls, supermarkets, barbers, and hairdressers will only be open for service during the hours of 10:00-20:00. Restaurants in hotels/accommodation facilities will be open, but available only for hotel guests only.  Link: https://archive.fo/uEtHR and https://archive.fo/3lgF0
Busses, ferries, and trains are operating, but there are limits to passenger capacity on buses and all passengers must wear a mask.   Link: https://archive.fo/3lgF0
Link: https://archive.fo/uEtHR

Intercity travel permits are required for Turkish citizens and residents aged 65 and over. Foreigners in the country temporarily for tourism are exempt from curfews and travel permit requirements.  Link: https://archive.fo/uEtHR and https://archive.fo/3lgF0
There are screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry. A PCR test is required only for passengers with symptoms for COVID-19.   Link: https://archive.fo/wip/3lgF0

Ministry of Health updated on 3rd of September 2020 “COVID 19 Guide” (including “COVID-19 Outbreak Management and Study Guide”, “General Information, Epidemiology and Diagnosis”, “Infection, Control and Isolation” materials).  Links: https://archive.fo/NCoEa

Starting with 8th of September, citizens are obliged to wear masks without exception in all areas (public areas, avenues, streets, parks, gardens, public transportation vehicles, workplaces) across the country, excluding residences.   Link: https://archive.fo/wip/QF9El and https://archive.fo/wip/s79gn

From 13 November 2020, the Government has introduced a weekend quarantine until November 30, 2020. Also, anti-epidemic restrictions that were in effect for the orange quarantine zone will now apply to all regions of the country.  What is forbidden?  Visiting by a group of more than 20 persons of educational institutions, except for preschool, general secondary, out-of-school and specialized education institutions  Visiting preschool, general secondary, out-of-school, sports and art education institutions when more than 50% of students and staff of the educational institution stay in self-isolation    https://web.archive.org/web/20201114174953/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/uryad-zaprovadiv-karantin-vihidnogo-dnya-onovleno

No evidence of additional policy changes. Adaptive quarantine in place until December 31 and weekend quarantine continues to November 30.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201125013008/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/timeline?type=posts&category_id=13&tag=Healthcare

From 13 November 2020, the Government has introduced a weekend quarantine until November 30, 2020. Also, anti-epidemic restrictions that were in effect for the orange quarantine zone will now apply to all regions of the country.  What is forbidden?  Operation of public catering establishments from 22:00 to 7:00 (except delivery of takeaway orders), and also operation of public catering establishments with the organization of leisure, work of night clubs  Activities of accommodation facilities (except hotels, rehabilitation centers for people with disabilities)  Visits to social protection institutions, with the stay of persons of senior age, and points of temporary stay of foreigners and stateless persons  Operation of gyms, fitness centers and museums, if they have more than 1 person per 20 m2    https://web.archive.org/web/20201114174953/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/uryad-zaprovadiv-karantin-vihidnogo-dnya-onovleno

According to the press release from the office of the President of Uzbekistan on 24 November 2020, 96 thousand enterprises that had to suspend their work during the pandemic have already resumed their activities. The government is providing assistance in restoring other business entities. See article from the office of the President of Uzbekistan, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20201128104003/https://president.uz/ru/lists/view/3970

From September 5 onwards, public prayers are allowed in religious organisations with no upper limit of crowd size. However, other gatherings are limited to 30 persons. See Ministry of Health telegram channel, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20201107121041/https://t.me/s/ssvuz/2822 AND https://web.archive.org/web/20201107124206/https://t.me/s/koronavirusinfouz/5657

Extension of expiring child benefits by 1 year; delivery of a food basket to persons with disabilities, elderly. See European Bank for Reconstruction and Development policy update, archived: https://www.ebrd.com/documents/admin/uzbekistan-coronavirus-policy-response.pdf?blobnocache=true
